response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to appropriate funds for the continued implementation of the kauhale initiative and the ohana zones pilot program. [CHUNK_15] It also appropriates funds for the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services for households with special needs. [CHUNK_16] This measure provides funding to further expand affordable housing inventory and supportive services for individuals experiencing or at the risk of homelessness throughout the State. [CHUNK_41]",
  "appropriations": "The bill appropriates an unspecified sum out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative. [CHUNK_17] It also appropriates an unspecified sum for the same fiscal years for the continued implementation of the ohana zones pilot program. [CHUNK_21] A third unspecified appropriation for the same fiscal years is made to the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation for the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects. [CHUNK_27]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The fiscal note is based on the legislative finding that it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. [CHUNK_14] It assumes continued funding is needed for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and the Kauhale Initiative, which aim to provide supportive housing and services with an emphasis on community-based solutions. [CHUNK_40] Historical appropriations include $30,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt) initially for the ohana zones pilot program, $15,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt) for an extension, and $25,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt) for the kauhale initiative, which informs the scale of potential funding. [CHUNK_3, CHUNK_6, CHUNK_8]",
  "agency_impact": "The sums appropriated for the kauhale initiative and the ohana zones pilot program shall be expended by the office of the governor. [CHUNK_20, CHUNK_22] The sums appropriated for supportive housing projects shall be expended by the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. [CHUNK_28] Language that would have allowed the Governor to transfer appropriations for the Kauhale Initiative to other executive branch departments or agencies was deleted. [CHUNK_43, CHUNK_44]",
  "economic_impact": "The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. [CHUNK_1] This measure aims to expand affordable housing inventory and supportive services for individuals experiencing or at the risk of homelessness throughout the State. [CHUNK_41] Funding the kauhale initiative is intended to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. [CHUNK_8]",
  "policy_impact": "This measure continues funding for both the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and the Kauhale Initiative. [CHUNK_40] It amends a previous version by deleting language that would have established a Supportive Housing Special Fund. [CHUNK_47] Instead, it now provides a direct appropriation to the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for the development of supportive housing projects. [CHUNK_48]",
  "revenue_sources": "Appropriations for the kauhale initiative, the ohana zones pilot program, and the supportive housing projects are made out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_16, CHUNK_20, CHUNK_26] The bill does not identify other revenue sources. [CHUNK_16, CHUNK_20, CHUNK_26] The previous proposal to create a Supportive Housing Special Fund, which could have had its own revenue mechanisms, was deleted. [CHUNK_47]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The bill appropriates unspecified sums from the general fund for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 for three distinct purposes: the kauhale initiative, the ohana zones pilot program, and HHFDC supportive housing projects. [CHUNK_17, CHUNK_21, CHUNK_27] While the amounts are blank, historical context suggests significant investment. [CHUNK_50] The ohana zones pilot program was initially appropriated $30,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt), with subsequent appropriations of $2,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt) and $15,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_3, CHUNK_4, CHUNK_6] In 2023, the legislature set aside $25,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt) for the kauhale initiative. [CHUNK_8] A supportive housing pilot program in 2023 was also funded with $5,000,000 (HB431_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_6, CHUNK_7] The continued implementation of these programs implies ongoing annual costs for operations, rent supplements, support services, and administration. [CHUNK_18] The development of new supportive housing projects by HHFDC will represent a significant capital investment. [CHUNK_25] Given the extension of the ohana zones pilot program to 2026 and the ongoing nature of the kauhale initiative, these programs will likely require appropriations beyond the two fiscal years in the bill, creating a multi-year fiscal commitment. [CHUNK_6, CHUNK_11] The Committees requested that the Office of the Governor provide the necessary amounts for these initiatives to the Committee on Ways and Means. [CHUNK_50, CHUNK_51]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided documents do not contain information regarding impacts on operating revenues. [CHUNK_0, CHUNK_1, CHUNK_2, CHUNK_3, CHUNK_4, CHUNK_5, CHUNK_6, CHUNK_7, CHUNK_8, CHUNK_9, CHUNK_10, CHUNK_11, CHUNK_12, CHUNK_13, CHUNK_14, CHUNK_15, CHUNK_16, CHUNK_17, CHUNK_18, CHUNK_19, CHUNK_20, CHUNK_21, CHUNK_22, CHUNK_23, CHUNK_24, CHUNK_25, CHUNK_26, CHUNK_27, CHUNK_28, CHUNK_29, CHUNK_30, CHUNK_31, CHUNK_32, CHUNK_33, CHUNK_34, CHUNK_35, CHUNK_36, CHUNK_37, CHUNK_38, CHUNK_39, CHUNK_40, CHUNK_41, CHUNK_42, CHUNK_43, CHUNK_44, CHUNK_45, CHUNK_46, CHUNK_47, CHUNK_48, CHUNK_49, CHUNK_50, CHUNK_51, CHUNK_52, CHUNK_53, CHUNK_54, CHUNK_55]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The measure appropriates funds for the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects. [CHUNK_25] The funds for the kauhale initiative include expenses related to the development and operation of kauhale. [CHUNK_18] Historically, ohana zone funds were appropriated for the construction of modular temporary units and renovation of existing structures. [CHUNK_4]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The bill supports long-term solutions to homelessness such as supportive housing and affordable housing. [CHUNK_11] The continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program, along with the development of new supportive housing, will likely require sustained funding beyond the initial two-year appropriation period. [CHUNK_40] These initiatives represent an ongoing fiscal commitment to address the State's high rate of homelessness. [CHUNK_1]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This version of the measure has been significantly amended from the previous version which focused on creating a Supportive Housing Special Fund. [CHUNK_34] Key changes include deleting the language that would have established the Supportive Housing Special Fund and its associated appropriations. [CHUNK_47] The amended measure now inserts a blank appropriation to be directly expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for supportive housing projects. [CHUNK_48] Additionally, language that would have allowed Kauhale Initiative funds to be used for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program was deleted, creating separate funding streams for each program. [CHUNK_42] Language authorizing the Governor to transfer Kauhale Initiative appropriations to other departments was also deleted. [CHUNK_43]",
  "fte_positions": "The provided documents do not contain information regarding Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions, although appropriations for the kauhale initiative include funding for staffing and related costs to administer the initiative. [CHUNK_18]",
  "appropriations_changes": "The measure was amended to delete language that would have made appropriations into and out of a new Supportive Housing Special Fund. [CHUNK_48] In its place, the bill now inserts a blank appropriation amount for the continued implementation of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and a separate blank appropriation amount for supportive housing projects to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation. [CHUNK_46, CHUNK_48] This clarifies three distinct, though unspecified, appropriations for the Kauhale Initiative, Ohana Zones, and HHFDC supportive housing. [CHUNK_17, CHUNK_21, CHUNK_27]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "The funding source remains the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_16, CHUNK_20, CHUNK_26] The primary change is the method of funding for supportive housing; instead of capitalizing a new special fund, this version provides for a direct general fund appropriation to the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation. [CHUNK_47, CHUNK_48]",
  "department_impact": "The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation is no longer tasked with administering a new Supportive Housing Special Fund, as that provision was deleted. [CHUNK_47] Instead, the corporation is now the expending agency for a direct appropriation for the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects. [CHUNK_28] The office of the governor remains the expending agency for funds for the kauhale initiative and the ohana zones pilot program. [CHUNK_20, CHUNK_22]",
  "reports_required": "The provided documents do not contain information regarding reporting requirements. [CHUNK_0, CHUNK_1, CHUNK_2, CHUNK_3, CHUNK_4, CHUNK_5, CHUNK_6, CHUNK_7, CHUNK_8, CHUNK_9, CHUNK_10, CHUNK_11, CHUNK_12, CHUNK_13, CHUNK_14, CHUNK_15, CHUNK_16, CHUNK_17, CHUNK_18, CHUNK_19, CHUNK_20, CHUNK_21, CHUNK_22, CHUNK_23, CHUNK_24, CHUNK_25, CHUNK_26, CHUNK_27, CHUNK_28, CHUNK_29, CHUNK_30, CHUNK_31, CHUNK_32, CHUNK_33, CHUNK_34, CHUNK_35, CHUNK_36, CHUNK_37, CHUNK_38, CHUNK_39, CHUNK_40, CHUNK_41, CHUNK_42, CHUNK_43, CHUNK_44, CHUNK_45, CHUNK_46, CHUNK_47, CHUNK_48, CHUNK_49, CHUNK_50, CHUNK_51, CHUNK_52, CHUNK_53, CHUNK_54, CHUNK_55]",
  "pilot_program": "The bill provides for the continued implementation of the ohana zones pilot program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018. [CHUNK_22] The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. [CHUNK_5] Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026. [CHUNK_6]",
  "sunset_date": "Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026. [CHUNK_6] This bill does not contain a sunset date for its own provisions. [CHUNK_29]",
  "effective_date": "This Act shall take effect on June 29, 3000. [CHUNK_29] The sections containing the appropriations are specified to take effect on July 1, 3000. [CHUNK_29]"

chunk_details.chunk_text: HB431 SD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 431 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 2 STATE OF HAWAII S.D. 1 A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest

SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The 2024 Point In Time Count showed a total of 6,389 people experiencing homelessness in the State. The majority of the homeless are on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred

on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred fifty-four, and Kauai with five hundred twenty-three homeless individuals. Between 2023 and 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless

experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act

nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make

structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act

ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program

set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly;

with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest

time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale was envisioned as "prefabricated homes, or other modest, low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an

low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office building, so long as there is communal space and an investment in building communal responsibility." Over time, the kauhale initiative has evolved to a range of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at

of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now include temporary, time-limited options such as emergency shelter, medical respite, and mobile outreach and navigation, as well as long-term solutions such as supportive housing and affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds

affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the important principles of the State's kauhale initiative is building partnerships between government and community, providing affordable spaces for housing and healing, and fostering belonging and responsibility. Every kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible

kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used to empower community champions to fill resource gaps where needed. The legislature also finds that to ensure there is capacity within the State to meet the needs for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness,

for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to appropriate funds for: (1)

purpose of this Act is to appropriate funds for: (1) The continued implementation of: (A) The kauhale initiative; and (B) The ohana zones pilot program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018; and (2) The development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of

maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services for households with special needs who reside in the supportive housing projects. PART II SECTION 2. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as

Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative , including expenses related to: (1) The development and

initiative , including expenses related to: (1) The development and operation of kauhale; (2) The provision of project-based rent supplement payments; (3) The provision of support services for qualified individuals and families in kauhale; (4) Staffing and related costs to administer the kauhale initiative; (5) Addressing basic needs of individuals

administer the kauhale initiative; (5) Addressing basic needs of individuals and families experiencing homelessness; (6) Wrap around services; (7) Social and health care services; (8) Transportation; and (9) Other services with the goal of alleviating poverty and transitioning individuals and families experiencing homelessness or housing instability into supportive or affordable

families experiencing homelessness or housing instability into supportive or affordable housing. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the office of the governor for the purposes of this part. SECTION 3. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so

the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued implementation of the ohana zones pilot program established under Act 209,

of the ohana zones pilot program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the office of the governor for the purposes of this Act. PART III SECTION 4. The legislature finds that combining affordable housing with access to services to help

that combining affordable housing with access to services to help special needs populations, such as individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals,

disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals, live more stable and productive lives. The legislature further finds that the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation administers various programs to finance mixed-income rental housing developments. legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. chunks.chunk_text: HB431 SD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 431 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 2 STATE OF HAWAII S.D. 1 A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest

SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The 2024 Point In Time Count showed a total of 6,389 people experiencing homelessness in the State. The majority of the homeless are on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred

on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred fifty-four, and Kauai with five hundred twenty-three homeless individuals. Between 2023 and 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless

experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act

nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make

structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act

ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program

set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly;

with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest

time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale was envisioned as "prefabricated homes, or other modest, low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an

low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office building, so long as there is communal space and an investment in building communal responsibility." Over time, the kauhale initiative has evolved to a range of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at

of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now include temporary, time-limited options such as emergency shelter, medical respite, and mobile outreach and navigation, as well as long-term solutions such as supportive housing and affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds

affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the important principles of the State's kauhale initiative is building partnerships between government and community, providing affordable spaces for housing and healing, and fostering belonging and responsibility. Every kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible

kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used to empower community champions to fill resource gaps where needed. The legislature also finds that to ensure there is capacity within the State to meet the needs for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness,

for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to appropriate funds for: (1)

purpose of this Act is to appropriate funds for: (1) The continued implementation of: (A) The kauhale initiative; and (B) The ohana zones pilot program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018; and (2) The development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of

maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services for households with special needs who reside in the supportive housing projects. PART II SECTION 2. initiative , including expenses related to: (1) The development and operation of kauhale; (2) The provision of project-based rent supplement payments; (3) The provision of support services for qualified individuals and families in kauhale; (4) Staffing and related costs to administer the kauhale initiative; (5) Addressing basic needs of individuals

families experiencing homelessness or housing instability into supportive or affordable housing. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the office of the governor for the purposes of this part. disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals, live more stable and productive lives. enable the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of supportive housing units in stand-alone projects or integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The 2024 Point In Time Count showed a total of 6,389 people experiencing homelessness in the State. The majority of the homeless are on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred

on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred fifty-four, and Kauai with five hundred twenty-three homeless individuals. Between 2023 and 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless

experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act

nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make

structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act

ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program

set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly;

with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest

time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale was envisioned as "prefabricated homes, or other modest, low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an

low-cost housing unit", but "could also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office building, so long as there is communal space and an investment in building communal responsibility." Over time, the kauhale initiative has evolved to a range of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at

of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now include temporary, time-limited options such as emergency shelter, medical respite, and mobile outreach and navigation, as well as long-term solutions such as supportive housing and affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds

affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the important principles of the State's kauhale initiative is building partnerships between government and community, providing affordable spaces for housing and healing, and fostering belonging and responsibility. Every kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible

kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used to empower community champions to fill resource gaps where needed. The legislature also finds that to ensure there is capacity within the State to meet the needs for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness,

for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to appropriate funds for: (1)

purpose of this Act is to appropriate funds for: (1) The continued implementation of: (A) The kauhale initiative; and (B) The ohana zones pilot program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018; and (2) The development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of

maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services for households with special needs who reside in the supportive housing projects. PART II SECTION 2. initiative , including expenses related to: (1) The development and operation of kauhale; (2) The provision of project-based rent supplement payments; (3) The provision of support services for qualified individuals and families in kauhale; (4) Staffing and related costs to administer the kauhale initiative; (5) Addressing basic needs of individuals

administer the kauhale initiative; (5) Addressing basic needs of individuals and families experiencing homelessness; (6) Wrap around services; (7) Social and health care services; (8) Transportation; and (9) Other services with the goal of alleviating poverty and transitioning individuals and families experiencing homelessness or housing instability into supportive or affordable

families experiencing homelessness or housing instability into supportive or affordable housing. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the office of the governor for the purposes of this part. SECTION 3. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so

the State of Hawaii the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued implementation of the ohana zones pilot program established under Act 209,

of the ohana zones pilot program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the office of the governor for the purposes of this Act. PART III SECTION 4. The legislature finds that combining affordable housing with access to services to help

that combining affordable housing with access to services to help special needs populations, such as individuals with alcohol or drug addiction; individuals transitioning from incarceration; youth aging out of foster care; domestic violence survivors; veterans; individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals,

disabilities, or mental illness; frail elderly; and chronically homeless individuals, live more stable and productive lives. The legislature further finds that the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation administers various programs to finance mixed-income rental housing developments. Providing funding will enable the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate

enable the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of supportive housing units in stand-alone projects or integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. The purpose of this part is to appropriate funds for the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of

housing projects and the provision of supportive services for households with special needs who reside in the supportive housing projects . The sums appropriated shall be expended by the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation for the purposes of this part. PART IV SECTION 6. This Act shall take effect

part. PART IV SECTION 6. This Act shall take effect on June 29, 3000; provided that sections 2, 3, and 5 shall take effect on July 1, 3000. Human Services and Housing, to which was referred H.B. No. 431, H.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING," beg leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and authorize

for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and authorize those funds to be used for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program; and (2) Establish and appropriate funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund. Your Committees received testimony in support of this measure from the Hawaii Housing Finance

in support of this measure from the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation; State Council on Developmental Disabilities; Department of Human Services; Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions; Office of Hawaiian Affairs; Office of Housing and Community Development of the County of Hawai ʻ i; Office of Housing of

the County of Hawai ʻ i; Office of Housing of the City and County of Honolulu; Hawai ʻ i State Youth Commission; Catholic Charities Hawai ʻ i; Hawai ʻ i Health & Harm Reduction Center; Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition; Maui Chamber of Commerce; Hawaii Young Adults in Transition; Hawai ʻ

Chamber of Commerce; Hawaii Young Adults in Transition; Hawai ʻ i Community Foundation; Pacific Housing Assistance Corporation; Hawai ʻ i Appleseed Center for Law & Economic Justice; Easterseals Hawaii; Young Democrats of Hawai ʻ i; Democratic Party of Hawai ʻ i; The Institute for Human Services, Inc.; and four individuals.

i; The Institute for Human Services, Inc.; and four individuals. Your Committees received comments on this measure from the Department of Budget and Finance and State Procurement Office . Your Committees find that to meet the State's needs for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is

solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. Your Committees further find that both the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and the Kauhale

that both the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and the Kauhale Initiative aim to provide supportive housing and services with an emphasis on community-based solutions. This measure provides funding for the continued implementation of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program and the Kauhale Initiative, in addition to funding for the Hawaii Housing

Kauhale Initiative, in addition to funding for the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services, to further expand affordable housing inventory and supportive services for individuals experiencing or at the risk of homelessness throughout

for individuals experiencing or at the risk of homelessness throughout the State. Your Committees have amended this measure by: (1) Deleting language that would have allowed funds appropriated for the continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative to be used for the Ohana Zones Pilot Program established under Act 209, Session

the Ohana Zones Pilot Program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018 ; (2) Deleting language that would have allowed: (A) The Governor to transfer all or a portion of the appropriations for the continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative to the Governor's designated executive branch departments or

Kauhale Initiative to the Governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies, including the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions, for expenditures incurred to implement the Kauhale Initiative; and (B) The Governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies to expend the transferred appropriations for the performance of their duties under

the transferred appropriations for the performance of their duties under the Kauhale Initiative; (3) Deleting language that would have provided that if funds appropriated for the continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative are used to contract for the procurement of building services and projects related to the Kauhale Initiative, there

building services and projects related to the Kauhale Initiative, there shall be at least two bidders for any kauhale project estimated to be over $1,000,000; (4) Inserting a blank appropriation amount for the continued implementation of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018

Program established under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018 ; (5) Deleting language that would have established a Supportive Housing Special Fund to be administered by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation ; (6) Deleting language that would have made appropriations into and out of the Supportive Housing

have made appropriations into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund; (7) Inserting a blank appropriation amount to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services for households with special

and the provision of supportive services for households with special needs who reside in the supportive housing projects ; (8) Amending the legislative findings of part III to reflect its amended purpose; (9) Amending section 1 to reflect its amended purpose; and (10) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes

purpose; and (10) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity and consistency. Your Committees note that this measure contains unspecified appropriation amounts. Your Committees respectfully request that the Office of the Governor provide to your Committee on Ways and Means the amounts necessary for the continued implementation of

and Means the amounts necessary for the continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program respectively, and the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable supportive housing projects and the provision of support services for households with special needs who reside in the supportive housing projects by the

needs who reside in the supportive housing projects by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation, should your Committee on Ways and Means choose to deliberate on this measure. As affirmed by the records of votes of the members of your Committees on Health and Human Services and Housing that

your Committees on Health and Human Services and Housing that are attached to this report, your Committees are in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 431, H.D. 2, as amended herein, and recommend that it pass Second Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 431,

Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 431, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, and be referred to your Committee on Ways and Means. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the members of the Committees on Health and Human Services and Housing, ________________________________ STANLEY CHANG, Chair ________________________________ JOY A. overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.
